text: Is it possible to run flumine just as a "market recorder", with all the other features turned off? (for ex. turning off OrderStreaming)

elements.text: Is it possible to run flumine just as a "market recorder", with all the other features turned off? (for ex. turning off OrderStreaming)

text: Yep, this is a client setting <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/d9c0d51a94c32cb5972d45a0806791cd1e72e56b/flumine/clients/baseclient.py#L26>

elements.text: Yep, this is a client setting

text: How often is market_recorder.py processing Market Catalogues and is it writting this info in the files?

elements.text: How often is market_recorder.py processing Market Catalogues and is it writting this info in the files?

text: Every time you see a market for the first time OR when the market version changes

elements.text: Every time you see a market for the first time OR when the market version changes

text: And if yuo read the code: <https://github.com/liampauling/flumine/blob/master/examples/strategies/marketrecorder.py>

attachments.title: examples/strategies/marketrecorder.py

elements.text: And if yuo read the code:

text: You'll notice it puts an object on S3 with the catalogue. You can change it to also dump it to a file locally if you want, or put it on S3 with another key

elements.text: You'll notice it puts an object on S3 with the catalogue. You can change it to also dump it to a file locally if you want, or put it on S3 with another key

text: (For example, i change it to be in the same 'directory' as the market file because I run an S3 lambda on demand to update an index everytime one gets uploaded).

elements.text: (For example, i change it to be in the same 'directory' as the market file because I run an S3 lambda on demand to update an index everytime one gets uploaded).

text: I see it dumps it to a file locally under "/tmp" by default, but I don't see the catalogue being dumped. Can you point me at the part of the code that performs this?

elements.text: I see it dumps it to a file locally under "/tmp" by default, but I don't see the catalogue being dumped. Can you point me at the part of the code that performs this?

text: No it does not dump it on a file

elements.text: No it does not dump it on a file

elements.text: Look at line 185, you can put it there

text: (or i don't know how you organized your classes if you are basing it MR or S3-MR). process_closed_market is the hook

elements.text: It's very very simple ('create a bucket') once you got past the absolute contortion of the IAM roles. Plenty of stuff online.

wasabi.com
has the same API but it's cheaper.

text: Looks simple, and does flumine keep the connection with S3 always open? And appends lines to the files? Or does it upload the local files?

elements.text: Looks simple, and does flumine keep the connection with S3 always open? And appends lines to the files? Or does it upload the local files?

text: The latter one. There's no "append" in S3 in a srtict sense

elements.text: The latter one. There's no "append" in S3 in a srtict sense

text: dump -> zip locally -> upload

elements.text: dump -> zip locally -> upload

text: Surprised there is something cheaper than S3 tbh :laughing:

elements.text: Surprised there is something cheaper than S3 tbh

text: Got it, and isn't the upload of "big" files slowing down the whole process? This is python so I guess this is not done in parallel

elements.text: Got it, and isn't the upload of "big" files slowing down the whole process? This is python so I guess this is not done in parallel

text: Yep there is a todo as the upload is blocking so dont run live strategies with it...

elements.text: Yep there is a todo as the upload is blocking so dont run live strategies with it...

text: But its event driven using a queue so there is no impact

elements.text: But its event driven using a queue so there is no impact

text: You'd really not expect it heh? :smile:

elements.text: You'd really not expect it heh?

text: Also, tbh, while liam graciously fixed a related bug last week, I think running a recorder in a different process from your strategies is better. 1) you can record more than you actually bet on 2) in case one of the two starts having trouble doesn't affect the other one

elements.text: Also, tbh, while liam graciously fixed a related bug last week, I think running a recorder in a different process from your strategies is better. 1) you can record more than you actually bet on 2) in case one of the two starts having trouble doesn't affect the other one

text: (although flumine is robust enough since strategies run into separate exception blocks, I still find it better)

elements.text: (although flumine is robust enough since strategies run into separate exception blocks, I still find it better)

text: ah ok, but i don't see the big difference.. if you want to postprocess something complexly it may be worth separating it in a different process and juicing it inside through something, and Redis looks an OK way (plus you can have another subscriber that dumps to disk realtime). I guess it's a personal trade-off between isolated components and responsibilities versus monolithic/ease of maintenance.

elements.text: ah ok, but i don't see the big difference.. if you want to postprocess something complexly it may be worth separating it in a different process and juicing it inside through something, and Redis looks an OK way (plus you can have another subscriber that dumps to disk realtime). I guess it's a personal trade-off between isolated components and responsibilities versus monolithic/ease of maintenance.

text: Exactly, if on the flumine readme page it describes how you have to setup MySQL, Redis, streaming process and a event process before you can even start processing data I think the take up would be zero, instead its 10 lines of pure python with the ability to add all of the above if required

elements.text: Exactly, if on the flumine readme page it describes how you have to setup MySQL, Redis, streaming process and a event process before you can even start processing data I think the take up would be zero, instead its 10 lines of pure python with the ability to add all of the above if required

text: Yes agreed that having a 'scale complexity as you wish, but have a simple way to do it' is the best

elements.text: Yes agreed that having a 'scale complexity as you wish, but have a simple way to do it' is the best

text: Flumine's single process keeps things simple. I've been playing with Bitfinex's Python API. It is multithreaded, and that causes a headache with preventing duplicate orders being fired off.
